abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Implementation of
            Adaptation measures in Coastal Zones Project for Latin
            America and Caribbean is to 'support the efforts of
            Dominica, St. Lucia, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines to
            implement specific, integrated pilot adaptation measures
            that primarily address the impacts of climate change on
            their natural resource base, with a focus on biodiversity
            and land degradation along coastal and near-coastal
            areas.' The main reasons for the restructuring are:
            first, it is proposed to scale down the component and remove
            two of the three pilots in St. Vincent and the Grenadines.
            This change results in a reduction of two pilot activities
            out of the initial seven. The main reasons for the
            government's decision not to implement the two pilots
            are: (a) the high anthropological pressure on aquifers and
            surface waters, increased by a generalized water scarcity
            situation; and (b) the two other pilots have effectively
            stalled due to land related issues. No portion of the Global
            Environment Facility (GEF) grant has been used to finance
            these two pilots. Second, there is a need to adjust the
            project's outcome indicators to better reflect the
            nature of the interventions. Intermediate outcome indicators
            will also be changed accordingly. Third, some adjustments
            need to be made in the disbursement categories to allow for
            workshops and operating costs. Finally, the proceeds of the
            grant must be reallocated to compensate for the financial
            constraints that the participant countries have recently suffered.
